Summary of Proceedings: John Bartel was arrested and jailed upon an accusation of burglary and larceny. Bail was set at $300. John Stihling, whose relationship to Bartel is unclear, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Bartel posted bail and was released.

Summary of Proceedings: William Lemke petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his nine-year-old son, Paul Lemke, from the custody of Anna Guthmann, which was granted. The 1920 U.S. federal census indicates that William was a widower and that Paul was Anna's great nephew (presumably, Anna was the aunt of William's late wife and Paul's late mother). After hearing the evidence, the district court awarded custody of Paul to his father. Anna successfully appealed the case to the state supreme court, which overturned the ruling of the district court and returned Paul to the custody of his great-aunt.

Summary of Proceedings: Hiatt Walton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his five children from the custody of Etta Caton, superintendent of the Home for Dependent Children, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Walton's writ was denied and his children remanded to the custody of the Home. ; It is of possible interest that the hearing for this case was continued "by phone agreement."

["TouVelle, Guy T."](hc.pers.001155)|attorney|[State of Nebraska vs. G. A. Applegate](hc.case.ne.0695)
Summary of Proceedings: G. A. Applegate was arrested and jailed for violating a Lincoln, Nebraska city ordinance against "getting and become [sic] drunk." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the judge ruled that while the city ordinance allowed a person to be jailed if they did not pay their fine, the "part of said Ordinance imposing a sentence for said charge under said Ordinance is illegal and void." Applegate was remanded to the custody of his jailer and the police judge was ordered to set his bail at $200.

Summary of Proceedings: In May 1902, the Umatilla County Circuit Court sentenced R. E. Berry to six years in the Oregon State Penitentiary for "uttering forged evidence of debt." In June 1907, he petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Berry argued that he had served his time after accounting for a sentencing reduction as stipulated by a state law passed earlier that year. After hearing the evidence, Berry was released.

Summary of Proceedings: John Crawley was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. William Logan, whose relationship to Crawley is unclear, asserted that Crawley was a free man and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. Others asserted that Crawley was enslaved by a man named Stephen Gardier. After hearing the evidence, Crawley was released.

The next day, Holmes allowed the writ and ordered that Clarence be released into the custody of the petitioner. The relationship between the petitioner, bound party, and respondent is unknown, but it is presumed that Emma and Henry are the biological parents of Clarence.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Frank McCartney was being detained at the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and McCartney released from custody. The hospital superintendent appealed to the state supreme court, which overturned the decision of the lower court. Consequently, the writ was denied and McCartney remanded to the custody of the hospital superintendent.

Point(s) of Law Cited: It was "unlawful to sell mortgaged personal property, contrary to the provisions of the mortgage" in Colorado

Summary of Proceedings: George Schriner was jailed in Lancaster County, Nebraska and facing extradition to Morgan County, Colorado to respond to an accusation that he had violated a state ordinance making it "unlawful to sell mortgaged personal property, contrary to the provisions of the mortgage." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. Schriner contended that the extradition request did not allege that he had committed a crime, only that he had "sold mortgaged property." After hearing the evidence, Schriner was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Walter Scott, an employee of the Tabitha Home, and Jennie Adams, a long-term resident there, eloped in early October 1910. Scott petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in order to establish custody of his bride, which was granted. At the same time, a case to annul their marriage on the grounds that Adams was developmentally disabled and unable to give her consent was also before the court. While the annulment and habeas corpus proceedings were pending, Adams was placed into the temporary custody of one A. A. H. Mayer. Ultimately, the court annulled the marriage between Scott and Adams but also allowed Scott's writ. The result was that although Adams was released from the custody of the Tabitha Home, Scott had no legal authority to assert custody over her.

Summary of Proceedings: Joseph Ranzer was arrested and jailed upon an accusation of murdering his wife. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. His jailer, Gabriel Darlington, responded that Ranzer had already been "taken from [his] custody" by Louis du Breuil, a justice of the peace who had produced a warrant for Ranzer. Ranzer's fate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Leroy Allison was being detained at the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane on the authority of a warrant issued by the commissioners of insanity for Cass County, Nebraska. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, it was found that the commissioners had neglected to impose a sentence on Allison. The writ was allowed and Allison released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Samuel W. Smith accused a group of five men of shooting at him and his dog. Of the five, only Joseph Didier was arrested, charged with assault with attempt to kill, and jailed. The justice of the peace set bail at $500, which Didier did not pay. Citing several procedural irregularities, he petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Didier was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Dolly petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to secure her release from John Young, which was granted. Dolly accused John of assaulting and kidnapping her in St. Louis and then removing her to the Northwest Territory where he enslaved her for six months. Young pleaded not guilty and paid a recognizance agreeing that he would not remove Dolly from the court's jurisdiction. Her fate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: In 1903, Charles "Chick" Houghton was arrested in Multnomah County, Oregon, convicted of robbery, and sentenced to five years at the state penitentiary. In 1906, Houghton was granted "conditional clemency," or parole, by the governor and released from prison early with the understanding that he would be returned to finish his sentence if convicted of any crime. He was then arrested again in Multnomah County, convicted of larceny, and returned to the state penitentiary. Houghton appealed this decision to the state supreme court and then filed a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court, which was granted. Houghton argued that his detention was illegitimate since his conviction was under appeal. After hearing the evidence, the Circuit Court dismissed Houghton's petition and remanded him to the custody of the state penitentiary. Houghton immediately appealed this decision to the state supreme court, too. In early 1907, the state supreme court upheld the lower court's ruling.

Case Citation(s): St. Louis Circuit Court, Case Files, Box 150, Folder 28: July Term 1832, No. 57
Encoding Notes:
<airtable:mention id="menE9omj8ZKjM9DZ4">@Cory Young</airtable:mention> can you look at this case? the Henrys don't actually have Anson, though they are named as defendants; for that reason, I'm not sure they should be labeled as the holding parties; it turns out Hammand is the one with Anson in his custody, as he bought Anson from the Henrys...I'm wondering if Hammand is the holding party and the Henrys are kidnappers as case role; do you think this would correspond to other freedom suits?

<airtable:mention id="menZImXcrAYDydFL5">@Katrina Jagodinsky</airtable:mention> I would agree that Hammond is the holding party and that Mitchell and Russell are kidnappers in this case. But I don't believe it's because Hammond purchased Anson; I'm fairly sure he was the deputy sheriff acting as jailer. Hammond appears as the holding party in a few other of the Missouri cases. Plus, there's this incredibly problematic law enforcement webpage claiming he was killed in 1836 (https://www.odmp.org/officer/5990-deputy-sheriff-george-hammond). 

As for other freedom suits, I think we should distinguish between freedom suits, fugitive slave suits, and kidnapping suits. In kidnapping suits, the holding party is often going to be the kidnappers, although this suit shows that kidnappers occasionally deposited the people they seized with third parties. In freedom suits that don't involve kidnappers, the holding party is most likely going to be the enslaver. Is this helpful?

P.S. It occurs to me that we don't actually have the habeas petition for this case. We have the petition for a writ of trespass/assault/false imprisonment, and we have the writ of habeas corpus, but we don't have the petition for the writ of habeas corpus. Should we assume that William Clark supplied that petition, too?

<airtable:mention id="menHEbipq3ZBSbExy">@Cory Young</airtable:mention> this reading makes more sense to me; let's label Hammond as the holding party and jailer, while we label the Henrys as the kidnappers. I'm not ready to make a general rule, since I think many of these petitions will be idiosyncratic.

There's actually no habeas *petition*, here. Anson's next friend, William Clark, did not ask for the writ, but rather for five hundred dollars on a bill of trespass and assault. The judge appears to have issued a writ of habeas corpus of his own accord in order to proceed with the fact finding.
Petition Outcome: cause absorbed into related legal action
Petition Outcome Old: Petition granted: habeas initiates separate proceeding

Summary of Proceedings: By his next friend William Clark, Anson accused Henry Mitchel and Henry Russel of assaulting him with the intention of reducing him to slavery. The judge elected to issue a writ of habeas corpus. Mitchel and Russel were then arrested on kidnapping charges and Anson was jailed while awaiting his hearing. Mitchel and Russel pleaded not guilty, and Anson was ordered to be hired out while his status was being considered. See hc.case.mo.0019 and hc.case.mo.0020.

Summary of Proceedings: Phillis petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Julia from the custody of Robert Duncan and Sally Adams. Phillis asserted that she was a free woman, that Julia was her daughter, and that Robert and Sally were illegally enslaving the child. Robert and Sally claimed that they purchased Julia from John Sutton and, although they acknowledged Julia's freedom, cast doubts on Phillis' maternity while claiming that Julia wished to remain with them. Julia's fate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of premeditated murder, Archibald S. Jones petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sherriff Fred A. Miller was unlawfully depriving him of his liberty. He also claimed his right to bail. Judge Strode granted the petition. After reviewing the evidence, Strode ruled that Jones was not deprived of his liberty but was entitled to bail at a sum of five hundred dollars. It is unknown whether or not Jones posted bail.

Summary of Proceedings: John Owen was sentenced to five years in the Nebraska State Penitentiary in 1909 for unspecified reasons. In September 1910, he was granted parole by the governor. Owen found a job and began working, but was imprisoned the following month after the governor rescinded the parole. Owen petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus challenging the rescission, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Owen remanded to the custody of the penitentiary. He appealed to the state supreme court, which affirmed the decision of the lower court.

Summary of Proceedings: Aubrey Pickard petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Leonard Pickard from Genevieve Pickard and two others, which was granted. Although not specified in the documents, it appears likely that Leonard was Aubrey's son and Genevieve his ex-wife, as the judge had the cause "transferred to Judge Morning to be heard in connection with application to modify divorce decree." After hearing the evidence, Judge Morning dismissed the writ, awarded custody of Leonard to Genevieve, and ordered Aubrey to pay her court costs.

Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge the detention of Catiche, Helen, Julie, and Joseph, which was granted. Alexis Amelin responded that he was an agent for Alexander Scott, a steamboat captain and the enslaver of Catiche, Helen, and Julie. Amelin said he had placed those three in jail while awaiting their hearing. He also claimed that he had never had possession of Joseph, who he believed was enslaved by Pierre Chouteau, Sr. The fate of the four bound parties is unclear.

Summary of Proceedings: Notary Public J. S. Bishop subpoenaed Louis M. Cohn. When Cohn refused to provide information, Bishop charged him with contempt of court and ordered that he be jailed. Cohn petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sheriff Samuel McClay was depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Hall remanded Cohn to the custody of McClay. Case files for hc.case.ne.0551 reveal that Cohn appealed this decision to the Supreme Court. See hc.case.ne.0551.

Summary of Proceedings: C. H. Paul was jailed in Lincoln, Nebraska on suspicion of being a fugitive from justice in Colorado. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Paul was remanded to the custody of his jailers. The judge did not allow him to post bail and gave him forty days to file a bill of exception.

An unnamed party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve the girls, which was granted. Rolla Rose did not respond to the writ until threatened with contempt. He claimed not to have them. Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on an unknown crime allegedly committed in Montana, George M. Roe petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus and named James Malone, Henry Hoagland, Samuel McClay, and "Hunt" (first name unknown) as respondents. Judge Frost granted the petition and Malone produced Roe's body in court. After hearing evidence, Frost allowed the writ and judged that Roe be released from police custody. Hunt was unable to be located.

Summary of Proceedings: Found guilty of perjury in 1897 and sentenced to four years hard labor in the Nebraska State Penitentiary, in 1900 Leonard Kephart petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was eligible for "commutation for good behavior as provided for by Section 569" of Nebraska's Criminal Code. Therefore, he claimed that warden John H. Hopkins was unlawfully imprisoning him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Holmes allowed the writ and ordered that Kephart be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on an unknown charge, Frank Skipton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming Sheriff Trompen was depriving him of his liberty. Judge Frost granted the petition. Skipton later amended his petition, which Judge Frost also accepted. After hearing evidence, Judge Frost denied the writ and ordered that Skipton be remanded into custody. Skipton then filed an application to be admitted to bail, which Frost granted and fixed at 500 dollars. It is unknown whether Skipton followed through and posted bail.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of larceny, Michael J. Corrigan petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he had been denied his right to a speedy trial and that Sheriff Miller had no authority to jail him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Holmes remanded Corrigan back into custody. One month later, Corrigan filed a motion for a new trial, which was overruled.

He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, claiming Sheriff Miller was holding him illegally. Summary of Proceedings: After being charged with the murder of her husband, Mary E. Teller petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the hopes of either securing release or lowering her bail. The judge granted her writ but only to try the question of bail. He elected not to lower the bail and remanded Teller to the custody of her jailer to await trial.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: The Board of Commissioners for Gosper County, Nebraska found that John Wilken was a dipsomaniac, or alcoholic, and had him admitted to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane "until cured but not exceeding three years." Wilken petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the judge ruled that while the hospital could admit and detain Wilken, the Board of Commissioners had exceeded their authority in sentencing him for a period of time. The writ was denied and Wilken ordered to be returned to Gosper County to appear a second time before the Board of Commissioners.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with assault with intent to kill and sentenced to three years hard labor in the Nebraska State Penitentiary, Theodore G. Clark petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against warden John H. Hopkins. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Holmes denied the writ and ordered that Clark be remanded back into custody. Months later, Clark filed a motion for a new trial, which was overruled.

Summary of Proceedings: The Donohue family petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve a boy named Bernard Seward from the custody of the Noonan and Seward families, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Bernard was remanded to the custody of the Noonan and Seward families. Almost two years later, the Donohue family successfully challenged the jurisdiction of the court to hear the earlier proceedings. The outcome of this challenge and the fate of Bernard are unknown. See hc.case.ne.0702.

Summary of Proceedings: Oliver Lachapell was arrested, charged with using "obscene language in the presence of ladies," and jailed for 12 1/2 days after refusing to pay a $25 fine. Lachappel petitioned a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. He argued that cursing in front of women was not a crime, the act making it so having been repealed decades earlier. After hearing the evidence, Lachappel was released. See hc.case.or.0010.

Their father, Charles Sitzman, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve them, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the children were remanded to the custody of the respondents and their father ordered to pay the court costs. See hc.case.ne.0749.

Summary of Proceedings: Frank Smith petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Mollie Calhoun, a fourteen-year-old girl, from the custody of W. E. Miller and his wife, which was granted. Frank maintained that Mollie's father, Joseph Calhoun, had left Mollie in his charge when he left Oregon for the Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. Although Frank admitted that he had allowed Mollie to live with the Millers in the hope that she receive an education, he asserted that instead they were "making a slave out of her." During the hearing, Frank withdrew his petition. An entry on page 34 of the Marion County Probate Index suggests that Mollie remained with the Millers.

Summary of Proceedings: William Thayer petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve eleven-year-old John Medford from Thomas McNair, which was granted. Thayer claimed to be Medford's court-appointed guardian, while McNair claimed that Medford's mother had asked him to take care of the child on her deathbed. After hearing the evidence, Medford was released into Thayer's custody.

Summary of Proceedings: William O'Mara was sent to the St. Louis City Workhouse due to his inability to pay a $100 fine assessed on a misdemeanor conviction. An unknown party filed a writ of habeas corpus challenging the detention of William O'Mara and a woman named Margaret O'Mara, which was granted. The petition was ultimately withdrawn--perhaps because, according to workhouse superintendent, William Lingo, Margaret O'Mara was never sent to the workhouse.

Summary of Proceedings: Fred Swab was being detained at the Nebraska State Industrial School for Boys. Simon Swab, a presumed relative, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Fred remanded to the custody of the school superintendent.

Summary of Proceedings: John Whitney petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his daughter, Mary Whitney, from the custody of his late wife's parents, Nathan and Irena Tharpe, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Mary remanded to the custody of her father. The court, however, required that John allow Mary to spend at least ten days with her grandparents at least twice a year in order to keep custody.

Summary of Proceedings: William George Clarke, a man from Chicago, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his two sons, Holley (19) and Caryl (8), were being deprived of their freedom by Mary E. Lyon and H. E. Wood. The respondents were the half-sibling and in-law, respectively, of Annie Carpenter Clarke, the deceased ex-wife of the petitioner and mother of the bound party who had moved to Lancaster County with the children following the divorce in 1901. Judge Holmes granted the petition. The respondents claimed that they were appointed guardians of the bound party and given control of Annie's estate by her request after her death in 1906. They also alleged that the petitioner did not ever financially support his children after the divorce. Additionally, they claimed that he had a violent temper and was addicted to "intoxicating liquors," thus not making him a suitable guardian for his children. After hearing evidence, Judge Holmes denied the writ and ordered that the children remain in custody of Lyon and Wood, but that the petitioner be able to visit them at seasonable times. In the Court's decision, they also mention that the petitioner was currently going through another divorce from his second wife. Clarke then moved for the Court to grant him a new trial, which was overruled. The appearance docket shows that the NE Supreme Court affirmed the Court's decision in 1909.

Case Citation(s): RG207 Lancaster County Subgroup 9: Series 3 Appearance Docket H, p. 227; RG207 Lancaster County Subgroup 9: Series 4 Daily Journal Journal #56: Jan. 1910-Jan. 1911, p. 585

Summary of Proceedings: Frank G. Bevans petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his ten-year-old biological daughter, Gussie Bevans, was being deprived of her liberty by Frank's ex-wife and Gussie's mother, Winnie Crandall. Frank and Winnie had divorced years previously, and the court awarded custody to F. L. Knight, whose relationship to any named party is unknown. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In her response, Crandall claimed that Frank should not be given custody because he lives in Wyoming and that Knight was not a proper guardian because he had moved with his family to York, NE- away from Crandall. After reviewing the evidence, Judge Holmes ruled that custody of the bound party would be awarded to Louise R. Upton, Matron of the School for Girls (Brownell Hall) in Omaha, NE for five years. Frank G. Bevans filed two additional motions, one in June of 1900 and one in June of 1901, requesting that Gussie Bevans be allowed to spend summer vacation with her parents (equally split between them), which all parties agreed to.

Additional People: Clark, Enos; Mercer, J. R.; Phillips, R. O.

Summary of Proceedings: Fayette I. Foss, attorney for David Zimmerman's company, petitioned on behalf of Zimmerman claiming that Sheriff of Furnas County, Nebraska had deprived him of his liberty. Zimmerman had been arrested on a bench warrant issued by district judge D. T. Welty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, he ruled that Zimmerman be released on his own recognizance after surrendering a sum of five hundred dollars, which Zimmerman did.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Mary Ann Scheiber left her husband, Joseph Schieber, and took their son, Edward Schieber, with her. Joseph petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to retrieve Edward from Mary Ann and Henry Steinberg, whom Joseph accused of being Mary Ann's lover. The petition was granted and at the hearing "proof [was] heard, and refused," suggesting that the writ was denied and Edward remained with his mother.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: John Bellamy was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. Frank Burke, who knew Bellamy since he was a child and knew him to be free, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. At the hearing, multiple witnesses confirmed that Bellamy was free. He was ultimately released.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Patrick Kennedy was arrested and jailed upon an accusation of perjury. Bail was set at $500. Kennedy had recently accused Walter P. McAfee of assault and battery; McAfee responded by accusing Kennedy of lying under oath. Kennedy cited procedural irregularities leading to his detention and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Kennedy was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of murder, George W. Davis petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that James Malone and P. H. Cooper were depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition, but after discovering that neither Malone nor Cooper had custody of Davis, he denied and dismissed the writ. Davis was found in the prison of the city of Lincoln. No holding party appeared, and Judge Hall ruled that Davis should remain imprisoned.

Summary of Proceedings:
Louis M. Cohn petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus arguing that Sheriff McClay was depriving him of his liberty. Weeks previous, Cohn had successfully petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, was remanded to custody, and filed an appeal in the Supreme Court. While that petition was pending, Cohn successfully petitioned for a writ after he had been remanded into custody again. Judge Tibbetts ruled that because Cohn had been committed a second time for the same offense, Cohn was deprived of his liberty. Tibbetts ordered that Cohn be released.
See hc.case.ne.0550.

Summary of Proceedings: After Mary Marshall and her son William Marshall entered the Home for the Friendless in 1884, William was struck ill and referred to Hattie R. Painter, a physician, and her presumed relative, Joseph Painter. In 1886, Mary Marshall petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that William Marshall was unlawfully deprived of his liberty by Hattie and Joseph Painter. After hearing testimony, Judge Pound declared that William Marshall was not deprived of his liberty. Although he ordered that William remain in the custody of the holding party, Pound ordered that the petitioner be able to visit her son at all reasonable times and that in six months she could petition to modify the custody agreement.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on the charge of "getting and becoming drunk and indulging in loud, boisterous and tumultuous conduct," Susie Blue and Mary Woods petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Chief of Police Hoagland was unlawfully detaining them. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After hearing evidence, he allowed the writ and ordered that Blue and Woods be released from custody. Months later, Hoagland moved for a new trial, which was denied.

Summary of Proceedings: Edward Thacker, father and guardian of Addie Thacker, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Addie Thacker was being unlawfully detained by Dora Doyle. According to secondary research, Doyle was police matron. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Holmes appointed W. W. Towle, attorney for petitioner, as the guardian of the bound party and ordered that the petitioner pay for the care and maintenance of bound party. All parties agreed to this new custody arrangement.

Summary of Proceedings: Lafayette Robinson was being detained for unspecified reasons. Jane Williams, whose relationship to Robinson is unclear, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on his behalf, which was granted. In the meantime, Robinson posted a $200 bail and was released. The respondents failed to answer the writ, and so Robinson was released from their custody. Peter Johnstone, the police chief, was ordered to pay Williams' court costs.

Summary of Proceedings: Blanche Folson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge her detention at the "Hospital for the Insane at Hastings," now the Hastings Regional Center, which was granted. Folson claimed that her parents had assaulted her and had her committed to the asylum on false pretenses. Folson mentioned a husband and three young children. After hearing the evidence, which included commitment papers, Folson was remanded to the custody of the superintendent.

Summary of Proceedings: After hearing evidence from Adrian Mills, Viola Mills' father, regarding Viola being "incorrigible" and growing up "in vice," County Judge Stewart ordered that Viola be institutionalized at the State Reform School in Kearney, Nebraska. Days later, Viola Mills petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sheriff Samuel McClay was depriving her of her liberty. The petition was granted by Judge Addison Tibbetts. After hearing evidence, Judge Tibbetts ordered that Viola be released.

Summary of Proceedings: Ardula Porter petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to regain custody of her daughter, thirteen-year-old Clara Barnes, from her brother-in-law, J. C. Barnes, which was granted. Ardula and Joseph Barnes had gotten divorced without establishing custody of their daughter, Clara, who had been living with her father and his family when he died. According to Ardula, Joseph's brother, J. C., was refusing to allow Ardula to take custody of her daughter. The petition was dismissed during the hearing "without costs to any of the parties, the said child having ben surrendered to the petitioner."

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: The Board of Insanity for Kearney County, Nebraska had Scott Brainard committed to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court determined that the board had improperly sentenced Brainard, although the rest of the "proceedings in relation thereto were regular." The court remanded Brainard into the custody of the state hospital but gave the board forty-eight hours to re-sentence him, otherwise he would be discharged.

Summary of Proceedings: Frank D. Soverign claimed that he was unlawfully jailed by Constable Robert Mitchell and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. Justice of the Peace R. W. Taylor had ordered for Soverign to be jailed on the charge of "maliciously killing a wild bird" (a hawk). After hearing evidence, Judge Pound remanded Soverign to the custody of the jailer. The appearance docket records a Supreme Court mandate on July 22, 1878, but the outcome of that mandate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and convicted in the District Court of Sheridan County on the charge of grand larceny for stealing a cow, Herman Granger petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary Leidigh was unlawfully detaining him. He had previously appealed to the Nebraska State Supreme Court, who had upheld the verdict. Granger argued that he was imprisoned under the NE House of Representatives bill no. 87 "an act to punish cattle stealing..." when the bill had not passed, making his incarceration unconstitutional. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Holmes denied the writ and remanded Granger back into the custody of the warden.

Summary of Proceedings: Henry Leonari enlisted in the U.S. Army. He later claimed to be a minor and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. His brother, Rufus Leonari, declared that Henry was a minor and that both their parents were dead. After hearing the evidence, Henry was released. The case file includes notes on Commonwealth v. Thomas H. Cushing, Esq., an 1814 Massachusetts case holding that children without "parents, guardians or masters" could not enlist in the U.S. military.

Augé accused Poupenez of illegally indenturing Quevereux; Poupenez countered that he held Quevereux by virtue of an indenture of apprenticeship agreed to by Quevereux's mother. After hearing the evidence, Quevereux was released.

Summary of Proceedings: On behalf of Edward and Martha Shelmidine, William H. Moore petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that they were unlawfully detained by Gable (first name unknown), Marshall of Waverly, NE. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In Gable's response, he alleges that he is holding the couple on orders of the Governor of Texas, Joseph D. Sayers, who issued an extradition warrant. In case files, Martha Shelmidine is also referred to as Mrs. M. M. Claxton. After reviewing evidence, Judge Cornish allowed the writ and ordered that the Shelmidines be released from custody. According to secondary source research, Martha was allegedly previously married in Texas and married Edward in Nebraska. She was allegedly facing charges of bigamy in Texas, which is presumably why Sayers issued an extradition warrant.

Summary of Proceedings: The Davis family petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Joseph R. Kimmel from the custody of the Kimmel family, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Joseph was remanded to the custody of the Kimmels. The Davises appealed to the state supreme court, which overturned the decision of the lower court. Ultimately, it was found that the child's father, Joseph M. Kimmel, had "voluntarily relinquished" his right to the boy. The court awarded custody of Joseph R. Kimmel to the Davis family but allowed his father to have him on Sundays as well as "four days in any month, with one week's notice."

William Edwards was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. He asserted that he was a free man and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Edwards was released. 

See hc.case.mo.0119.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Patrick McDonald, a thirteen year old boy, was arrested, accused of being a vagrant, and sent to the St. Louis House of Refuge. Bail was set at $100. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, contending that minors who had parents and homes could not be vagrants, which was granted. Michael McDonald, likely his father, witnessed the petition. After hearing the evidence, Patrick was remanded to the custody of F. S. W. Gleason, superintendent of the House of Refuge.

Summary of Proceedings: Belden Finley petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his son, Verne Finley, from the custody of Verne's grandparents, Jesse and May Carter, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Verne remanded into the custody of his grandparents. The judge ordered that Belden pay the Carters $3 per week, that the Carters teach Verne to "love and respect" Belden, that Belden be allowed to take temporary custody of Verne at "seasonable times," and that Belden be allowed to re-apply for custody of his son when he could better demonstrate his ability to care for him.

Summary of Proceedings: Andrew Rogers petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his young daughter, Lucy Rogers, from Francis Resser, which was granted. Rogers accused his wife of absconding with Lucy to Resser's home; Resser responded that Lucy and her mother were boarders and that he asserted no claim over the child. After hearing the evidence, Lucy was released into her father's custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Corra Cummings petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her ten-year-old daughter, Iona Cummings, from Charles and Alice Logan, which was granted. Corra had granted custody of Iona and her unnamed eight-year-old son to the Logans on the condition that they provide the children with a proper education. Corra contended that the Logans had neglected to honor their arrangement. After hearing the evidence, Iona was released into her mother's custody. It is unclear what happened to Corra's son.

Summary of Proceedings: Pearl Dils had taken her son, Willard Dils, to Boyd County, Nebraska while in the processing of divorcing her husband, James Dils. James petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Willard, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court ordered that James and Pearl share custody of Willard while their divorce was pending. Each was to have custody of Willard for one week at a time, dropping the boy off at the office of James' attorney, E. E. Spencer, on Saturday afternoons. Neither was to remove Willard from Lancaster County nor take him to their relatives' homes without permission of the other. Once this was decided, James withdrew his petition.

Summary of Proceedings: Mabel Best petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her twelve-year-old daughter, Isabel Sanderson, from the child's father, Jonathan Sanderson, which was granted. At the hearing, Mabel and Jonathan agreed to share custody of their daughter, modifying an earlier agreement recorded on page 665 of court journal number 71. It appears that the writ was amicably dismissed.

Summary of Proceedings: O. J. Vallecott, relationship to bound party unknown, petitioned on behalf of Benjamin D. Mills claiming that an unidentified John Doe had illegally deprived Mills of his liberty. Arrested on the charge of embezzlement and sentenced to serve time in the state penitentiary, Mills had appealed his case to the NE Supreme Court, who suspended his sentence and allowed him to enter into bail. Vallecott claimed that the order from the Supreme Court supersedes any order that John Doe was acting upon. Judge Holmes granted the petition. Half a year later, the court ordered that the action be dismissed. Fate of bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings:
After being arrested for allegedly "daylight house-breaking," Arthur Stull petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sheriff Miller was depriving him of his liberty. Judge Tibbetts granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, Tibbetts ruled that Stull be released from custody.

See hc.case.ne.0560.

Summary of Proceedings: Accused of embezzlement, Thomas Van Sciever was arrested on the order of Lorenzo Crouse, governor of Nebraska. Crouse received orders for extradition from W. H. Auble, agent of the state of California on behalf of W. H. Markham, governor of California. Thomas Van Sciever, and his agent and wife Addie Van Sciever, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that chief of police P. H. Cooper and agent W. H. Auble were depriving him of his liberty. Judge Hall granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Judge Tibbetts remanded him to the custody of Sherriff Miller. Van Sciever filed a writ of error and appealed to the Nebraska Supreme Court, who in 1897 affirmed the decision.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Institutionalized in the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane, Thomas Walton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against superintendent James L. Greene. Judge Frost granted the petition. When Walton was judged insane by a commission, they ruled that he was not dangerous and could be released. Walton's assigned guardian, John Taylor, also claimed that Walton had the means to provide for himself if released. After hearing this evidence, Judge Frost denied the writ and ordered that Walton be remanded back into the custody of Greene.

Summary of Proceedings: John Dick, Oscar Dick, and Nuema Jonrett were arrested and fined for disturbing the peace. The trio were jailed when they could not pay their fees. Nicholas Dick petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on their behalf, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the trio appear to have been released, since John and Oscar wasted little time filing suits for wrongful detainment. See Cases No. 5858 and 5859 in the same box.

Summary of Proceedings: John Krause petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his daughter, Augusta Krause, from a man named Cook, which was granted. According to John, Cook was holding Augusta in his house in St. Louis and would not allow her father to see her. After hearing the evidence, Augusta was released into John's custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Jacob Penner petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was unlawfully detained by James L. Greene, Superintendent of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane. Judge Cornish granted the petition. When Penner came before the court, Cornish ruled that Penner be released on his own recognizance. Cornish also set the hearing date for March 10th, 1906. The writ outcome and fate of the bound party are unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: T. Judson Ferguson was arrested, charged with forging a "contract or order on the Township of Alma, Harlan County, Nebraska for the sum of $50.00," and jailed. Bail was set at $350. Ferguson asserted that he was not guilty but did not post bail. He then asserted that the writ of mittimus was unlawful and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Ferguson was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska Childrens' Home Society (Douglas Co., NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Grace Miller, next friend and presumed relative of Herold James Miller, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Herold was being deprived of his liberty by Sadie Kingery, Elmer P. Quivey, and "the Nebraska Childrens' Home Society, a corporation." Quivery responded to the summons on behalf of the Nebraska Childrens' Home Society, a private adoption agency, and objected to the jurisdiction of the court over the Douglas County-based corporation. The court sustained the objection and dismissed the cause. The fate of the bound party is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Sam Harris was being jailed for unspecified reasons. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Harris was remanded to the custody of his jailer. Harris and his counsel made several attempts to contest this result, including motioning for a new trial, requesting bail, and preparing a bill of exceptions, but they do not appear to have succeeded in changing the judge's mind. While Harris' fate is unknown, he appears to have remained in jail.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings:
Michael Newland was arrested and jailed upon an accusation of "abducting Slaves" and selling them in New Orleans. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Newland was released.

This case mentions J. E. D. Couzins, who was captain of the St. Louis City Guard at the time. J. E. D. was the father of Phoebe Couzins, the first woman to serve as a U.S. Marshal.

Lindsey appealed to the District Court claiming that Sheriff Miller was unlawfully detaining him. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In his decision, Holmes ruled that the County Court was without jurisdiction, and Holmes ordered that Lindsey be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Ellis Harrison petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Margaret and Grace Harrison from the custody of Eileen Harrison, which was granted. At the hearing, Ellis withdrew his petition and was ordered to pay court costs. The fates of Margaret and Grace are unclear. Although nothing in the court documentation explicitly states the relationships between these parties, the 1920 census makes clear that this was a child custody case.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with highway robbery and sentenced to five years hard labor, June Bent petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary, George Leidigh. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Cornish denied the writ and ordered that Bent be remanded back into custody. Bent was tried along with his alleged co-conspirator, William Hayes, who also petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. See: hc.case.ne.0586

Summary of Proceedings: Joseph DeKlotz was being jailed on a charge of having engaged in "gambling, chance or fraud." He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted, the judge also ordering that he be released for the duration of the proceedings. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and DeKlotz released. The county attorney appealed this to the state supreme court, which affirmed the decision of the lower court.

Summary of Proceedings: Clifford B. Smith was arrested in Lancaster County on a warrant from Dakota Territory, which claimed he was guilty of grand larceny. Police Judge A. F. Parsons ordered Smith's detention with the intention of keeping him in police custody until he could be delivered to Dakota Territory authorities. Smith petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the jailer A. C. Langdon, which was unsuccessful. The verdict was later overturned in the Nebraska Supreme Court in April 1887 by Chief Justice Samuel Maxwell.

Summary of Proceedings: In 1903, Olive Anderson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that minor children Walter and Edna Gross were being deprived of their liberty by Minnie Gross and Henry Smalley. The relationship between the petitioner and the bound party is unknown. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In 1904, the court dismissed the cause "for want of prosecution." The next month, the petitioner showed in court and Judge Holmes reinstated the case. In 1906, the court again dismissed the cause. The fate of the bound party is unknown.

["Montgomery, Mary P."](hc.pers.000677)|bound party|["In the matter of the petition of J. B. Montgomery for the possession of Mary P. Montgomery, an infant, alleged to be detained by Sarah J. Montgomery"](hc.case.or.0002)
Summary of Proceedings: J. B. and Sarah Montgomery divorced in 1871. The Douglas County Circuit Court ordered that J. B., not Sarah, should have custody of their daughter, Mary Montgomery. Sarah refused to comply with the court order, prompting J. B. to petition for a writ of habeas corpus in Marion County, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the Marion County Circuit Court awarded custody of Mary to J. B., found Sarah to be in contempt, and ordered her to pay all court fees.

Summary of Proceedings: William McGiveren was lounging by the Meramec River with some friends when he made a remark that he thought it would be funny to drown Michael Gauly. Gauly had McGiveren arrested for disturbing the peace. Bail was set at $250. McGiveren petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, McGiveren was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Vera Baker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Thomas Smiley from the custody of William and Pearl Smiley, which was granted. At the hearing, counsel for the petitioner requested a recess to gather evidence in support of the "character of the home of the petitioner and its surroundings," which was also granted. At a second hearing six months later, the court denied the writ and remanded Thomas to the custody of the Smileys. Vera twice excepted to this judgement, but nothing came of her efforts.

Encoding Notes:
I think it is correct to say for these kinds of kidnapping suits where the judge allows the bound party to be hired out as a perverse kind of bail that the habeas petition was granted but the bound party remained in custody. The bound party certainly wasn't released. 

Similar to the Anson case, there is no habeas petition here.

Summary of Proceedings: Calvin Lambert jailed after being charged with murder. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Lambert was denied bail and remanded to the custody of his jailer. He appealed this decision to the state supreme court, which suspended the judgement of the lower court. Lambert's fate is unknown.

Summary of Proceedings: Louis Seiffer, alias David S. Berman, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that warden of the State Penitentiary Leidigh was depriving him of his freedom. Seiffer had been arrested on the charge of forgery, fined, and sentenced to five years imprisonment "and kept at hard labor." Seiffer claimed that before his initial trial in Furnas County's District Court, deputy sheriff A. E. Peterson insinuated that Seiffer would be lynched and hung and that the gathered crowd joined in the intimidation. Additionally, he claimed that he was told that if he pled guilty, he would only receive one year in prison. Judge Hall allowed the petition. After hearing evidence, Hall granted a Seiffer a "writ of relief" from the custody of Leidigh and ordered that Seiffer be transferred into the custody of Furnas County sheriff to await additional legal action. According to the August 11, 1895, Chicago Chronicle, Seiffer (spelled Seiffert) was a well-known forger throughout the United States.

Additional People: Burnett, George H.; DeGuire, C. F.

Summary of Proceedings: Benjamin Wise was arrested on suspicion of having committed arson, arraigned before the Justice Court of Salem, and jailed to await a grand jury trial. Bail was set at $2,000. Wise paid his bail and was released only to be promptly re-arrested and jailed to answer a second charge related to the arson. Bail was set at $3,000. Wise petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. He contended that the bail was excessive. After hearing the evidence, Wise was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Summary of Proceedings: On behalf of her next friend, Richard Seward, Kittie Noonan petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve a boy named Bernard Seward from the custody of the Donohue and Danaher families, which was granted. While the hearing was pending, Bernard was placed in the custody of Fannie Noonan. After hearing the evidence, it was determined that the petitioners retained "effectual custody" of Bernard and--since Bernard was not being detained--the cause was dismissed without prejudice. See hc.case.ne.0719.

Summary of Proceedings: Albert and Loretta Sheldon divorced in 1888. Five years later, Loretta, who had remarried, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to establish custody of their son, Hallie. Loretta claimed that the divorce settlement had not determined custody; Albert countered that the settlement had granted custody of Hallie and his brother, Olliver, to himself and custody of a third son, Walter, to Loretta. After hearing the evidence, Hallie was remanded to the custody of Albert and Loretta ordered to pay his court fees.

Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to release Hannah and Sarah from the custody of Francis Hickman, which was granted. In his response, Hickman claimed that two strangers attacked him on the way to the courthouse and "by force took the said girls from his possession." He later accused Rolla Rose of having been the kidnapper. The fates of Hannah and Sarah are unknown. See hc.case.mo.0023.

Summary of Proceedings: Molly Martin petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her son, Earl Martin, from his grandmother, Susie Harris, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Earl released into his mother's custody. The court, however, determined that both women were "fit and proper persons to have custody of said child," and allowed Susie to have custody of Earl one day each month and one month each summer. Molly petitioned to modify the custody arrangement a few times over the next several years, but was unsuccessful.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: The Commissioners of Insanity of Johnson County, Nebraska had Jacob Blessing committed to the Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane. Blessing claimed that he had not been permitted to testify at his commission hearing and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court found that "no valid sentence" had been "imposed upon said applicant," allowing the writ and releasing Blessing from custody.

Petition or Case Title: In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus
Point(s) of Law Cited: an ordinance to prevent the sale or exchange of property under the inducement that a gift or prize is to be part of the transaction; Sate V Long 74 Md. 565; Commonwealth V Emerson 165 Mass. 234; People V Gilpin 109 NY 389; Commonwealth V Sisson 50 NE Rep. 385; People V Dycker 72 App. Div. NY 308; State V Dalton 46 Atlantic Rep. RI 234
Primary field: In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Flaherty, James H."](hc.pers.001412)|petitioner, bound party|["In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0596)
["Woods, Frank H."](hc.pers.001413)|attorney|["In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0596)
["Holmes, Edward P."](hc.pers.000718)|judge|["In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0596)
["Routzahn, Olin M."](hc.pers.001414)|chief of police, respondent, jailer|["In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0596)
["Branson, Z. S."](hc.pers.001344)|sheriff|["In the Matter of the Application of James H. Flaherty, for a writ of Habeas Corpus"](hc.case.ne.0596)
Summary of Proceedings: Arrested after giving his customer trading stamps which could be redeemed at his company for merchandise, James H. Flaherty petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that the ordinance used to convict him in Police Court was unconstitutional, therefore, he was being deprived of his liberty. Judge Holmes granted the petition. In his statement, Holmes claimed that the charge and arrest dealt with public morality, not public safety, thus it was not a valid exercise of police power. He also ruled that Flaherty's method of advertising was not improper, and that the ordinance he was charged with violating was unconstitutional. He cites rulings in several other states. He allowed the writ and ordered that Flaherty be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arthur Smith, identified as an incompetent man, was detained at the Dr. Benjamin F. Bailey Sanitarium Company, also known as the Green Gables Sanitarium. His guardian, George Smith, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. At his hearing, the respondents mounted no defense and several doctors testified to Arthur's condition. After hearing the evidence, Arthur was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Milo Yates claimed that his infant son Frank Yates was illegally deprived of his liberty by Frank's mother and Milo's wife, Arizona. Milo Yates petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was served to Arizona in addition to Frank and Dorcas Rader (who are the presumed parents of Arizona and grandparents of Frank). After hearing the evidence, the bound party was released back into the custody of Arizona. Milo later filed a civil suit against Frank and Dorcas Rader, which was later dismissed without prejudice to further action.

Summary of Proceedings: William Blackburn was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. His mother-in-law, Sarah Broadwater, knew him to be a free man and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After a hearing during which multiple witnesses testified to Blackburn's free status, he was released.

Summary of Proceedings: An unknown party petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge the detention of a woman named Milly, which was granted. Mathias Rose, accused of detaining Milly, refused to respond to the petition and was consequently held in contempt of court. For background on this incident, see Kelly M. Kennington, In the Shadow of Dred Scott: St. Louis Freedom Suits and the Legal Culture of Slavery in Antebellum America (Athens: University of Georgia Press, 2017), 88-9.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: According to the appearance docket, on July 5th, 1902, Milton LaMaster, a seventy-four-year-old man declared insane, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against James L. Greene, superintendent of the Nebraska Home for the Insane. Judge Holmes presumably granted the petition because the AD claims that Greene received a copy. However, a simultaneous action was occurring regarding the legal status of the bound party. When Milton was declared insane, his attorney Charles Whedon was appointed guardian of his affairs. On July 9th, Milton's nephews Joseph LaMaster and Hugh Cooper petitioned for Joseph Weber (nephew of Milton) and Hugh LaMaster (brother of Milton) to be appointed guardians instead. They claimed that Whedon did not have Milton's best interests at heart because he was not a relative and allegedly had a strained relationship with him. They also claimed that because Whedon was helping Milton petition for a writ of habeas corpus, which implied that he believed Milton to not be insane, therefore not in need of a guardian. On July 15th, Milton moved to dismiss the cause, which Judge Cornish granted. That same day, Cornish granted guardianship to Whedon and Hugh LaMaster. Milton remained in the custody of Greene.

Summary of Proceedings: Hazel Allsman or her legal representative petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to challenge her detention by the Smith family, which was granted. While her hearing was pending, Allsman, who was a minor, was placed into the custody of Emily Hornberger, the county probation officer. Jesse Strode, the Lancaster County attorney, successfully motioned to have himself added to the case as a "party defendant on behalf of the State of Nebraska." After hearing the evidence, Allsman's writ was allowed and she was released from the custody of the Smith family.

Summary of Proceedings: John Martin served two years at the Nebraska State Penitentiary on a burglary conviction. The day he was released, he was arrested and charged with having committed an attempted robbery in Iowa several years prior. Martin claimed he had been in a different state at the time of the attempted robbery and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Martin released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested on the charge of grand larceny, Daniel S. Conroy petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Sherriff Miller was depriving him of his freedom. Judge Holmes granted the petition; however, after hearing evidence, he remanded Conroy back into custody. One month later, Conroy filed a motion to amend the record after Sherriff Miller admitted guilt. The motion was granted, but presumably Conroy remained in custody. Two years later, a Supreme Court decision affirmed the court's decision.

Petition or Case Title: Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris
Petitioners: hc.pers.000092|"Harris, Coley A. D. (Chloe Ann Harris)"|Female|Black
Primary field: Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Harris, Coley A. D. (Chloe Ann Harris)"](hc.pers.000092)|bound party, petitioner|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
["Hempstead, John"](hc.pers.000034)|jailer, respondent|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
["Colvin, John W."](hc.pers.000002)|judge|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
["MacDonald, Robert S."](hc.pers.000188)|attorney|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
["du Breuil, Louis"](hc.pers.000094)|authority ordering detention, justice of the peace|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
["Bartlett, Reuben"](hc.pers.000093)|kidnapper|[Habeas Corpus in the matter of Coley A. D. Harris](hc.case.mo.0083)
Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings:
Coley Harris was arrested and jailed on suspicion of being a fugitive from slavery. She declared that she was a free woman and petitioned the St. Louis Criminal Court for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted by one Judge Lackland. After hearing the evidence, she was released. However, Harris, in consultation with her attorney, was then arrested and jailed for a second time in an attempt to prevent her original kidnapper, Rueben Bartlett, from seizing her again. This time she petitioned the St. Louis Commissioner's Court for a writ of habeas corpus, which was also granted. Upon hearing the evidence, Harris was once again released.

Mark Twain believed that Harris had been posing as a slave to avoid punishment for having entered the state as a free Black woman without proper license. See Mark Twain's Letters, vol. 1, 1853 to 1866, eds. Edgar Marquez Branch et al (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1988), 51. (https://books.google.com/books?id=IPgkDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA51)

Summary of Proceedings: Frances Fidler petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to establish who should have custody of her daughter, Mary Thomas, then living with her grandmother, which was granted. By the mutual consent of both parties, they recessed for thirty days. At the hearing, Frances, alongside Mary's father, Archie Thomas, asked that custody of Mary be given to the child's grandmother, also named Mary Thomas. The judge agreed to this new arrangement, and Mary was remanded to the custody of her grandmother and namesake.

Summary of Proceedings: In July of 1887, Louis Leiberman, a Jewish naturalized U.S. citizen, was arrested on the charge of violating the city of Lincoln's Sunday ordinance. He argued in his habeas corpus petition that police judge Albert F. Parsons violated his right to due process and that his business, a general goods store, exempted him from following the ordinance; therefore, he was being deprived of his liberty by Marshall P. H. Cooper. In April of 1888, Judge Allen Field remanded Leiberman into custody until he was released on bond on April 24th on the sum of $100.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Napoleon Johnson was arrested and jailed. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted, asserting that he did not know any reason why he should be detained. His jailer responded that Johnson was being detained because a ship captain had accused him of "stealing a watch & pistol," but that the only witness, an unidentified Black man, could not testify because he was away on a boat. After hearing the evidence, Johnson was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Charged with highway robbery and sentenced to five years hard labor, William Hayes petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against the warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary, George Leidigh. Judge Cornish granted the petition. After reviewing the evidence, Cornish denied the writ and remanded Hayes back into the custody of Leidigh. Hayes was originally tried with his alleged co-conspirator, June Bent, who also petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. See: hc.case.ne.0585

Petition or Case Title: In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus
Primary field: In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus
RDF - person role case (from Case Role [: ["Holmes, Edward P."](hc.pers.000718)|judge|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
["Whedon, Charles O."](hc.pers.000191)|attorney|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
["Ress, Nicholas"](hc.pers.001069)|sheriff, jailer, respondent|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
["Decker, John F."](hc.pers.001422)|petitioner, bound party|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
["Caldwell, James L."](hc.pers.001067)|attorney|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
["Tyrrell, Frank M."](hc.pers.000863)|attorney|["In re Application of John F. Decker, for a writ of habeas corpus"](hc.case.ne.0598)
Summary of Proceedings: John F. Decker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was unlawfully detained by Sheriff Nicholas Ress. Judge Holmes granted the petition and allowed him bail at the sum of 300 dollars. Decker had been arrested on the charge of perjury after he falsely claimed during a divorce trial that he was a resident of Lancaster County, NE. After hearing evidence, Judge Holmes ruled that Decker had not committed perjury and therefore was being illegally detained. He ordered that Decker be released from custody. However, he ordered that the County Attorney, James L. Caldwell, prosecute Decker for the charge of contempt of court and punish him accordingly. Caldwell immediately followed through in State of Nebraska vs John F. Decker where again Decker was released on bail. The outcome of this case is unknown. Weeks later, Caldwell produced a motion for a re-hearing and a new trial for Decker's habeas corpus case, which the court overruled. In 1906, Caldwell's appeal was tried in the Nebraska Supreme Court, who later dismissed his petition in error.

Summary of Proceedings: Ray Rickard petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his daughter, Dorothy Rickard, from the custody of Catherine Kleeman and Martha Peer, which was granted. Martha responded that although her mother, Catherine, had Dorothy, who was her granddaughter, in her possession, neither woman claimed custody of the girl. After hearing the evidence, the judge ordered that Catherine either deliver Dorothy to her father or demonstrate in court why she should not have to do so. A few months later, Ray withdrew his petition, suggesting he had secured custody of Dorothy.

Judge Holmes granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Holmes denied the writ and remanded Frazier back into police custody. Holmes also ruled that Frazier be allowed to bail provided he pay the sum of 500 dollars. It is unknown whether Frazier posted bail.

Summary of Proceedings: Robert Welts was convicted of selling liquor without a license in Kearney County, Nebraska and fined $100. Since Welts could not pay, he was jailed. After serving for some time, he was released, only to be jailed again in Adams County. Welts declared that he was insolvent and had served long enough to satisfy his debt under state law. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Welts was released.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: After being institutionalized in Lincoln's Hospital for the Insane, William Golden initially petitioned for the appointment of a commission to determine his sanity. His petition was denied because he had not been admitted six months prior to the application. A week later, Golden petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that Supt. H. W. Mathewson had illegally deprived him of his liberty. Dr. Hay, S. J. Tuttle, A. C. RIcketts, and T. J. Fuller were subpoenaed. After hearing evidence, Judge Pound ordered that he be returned to Mathewson's custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Flora Ohler and Joseph Gielday divorced in January 1893. Custody of their two young daughters, Naomi and Leona Gielday, was awarded to Flora. According to Flora, she moved to Iowa and re-married, while Joseph moved to Red Willow County, Nebraska, and took ill. Flora allowed Naomi and Leona to visit Joseph in order to help take care of him. At some point, Leona returned to her mother while Naomi remained with her father. When Joseph died in February 1898, a pair of brothers named Charles and George Shafer contrived to have custody of Naomi awarded to Charles, arguing that she had no relatives living in the state. Flora petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve Naomi, which was granted. Flora argued that she was Naomi's rightful guardian and that Charles "only desires the custody of said minor child to gratify his own licentious designs and to accommodate the lust of his single brother George." Charles countered that Flora was an abusive mother, that Naomi remained with the Shafers of her own volition, and that the District Court of Lancaster County, Nebraska had no jurisdiction over Red Willow County. After hearing the evidence, fourteen-year-old Naomi Gielday was remanded to the custody of Charles Shafer.

Summary of Proceedings: J. H. Wilcox, next friend of bound party Lizzie Hendrickson, petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that sheriff deputy A. M. Trimble wrongfully placed Hendrickson in the Home for the Friendless. This case follows a county court habeas petition for Hendrickson's freedom, which was filed by her foster father, Nels Danielson. Judge Tibbetts granted Wilcox's petition. After hearing evidence, he judged that Lizzie be released from Trimble's custody.

Repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington (Seattle, WA)
Site(s) of Significance: King County Juvenile Detention Home (Seattle, WA)
Summary of Proceedings: Gladys Fuson, a married seventeen-year-old, was arrested in Port Townsend, the seat of Jefferson County, Washington, charged with delinquency after deserting her husband, and transported to the King County Juvenile Detention Home in Seattle. She petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus by her next friend, Lona McMasters, which was granted. Gladys, whose husband, Harold Fuson, was seeking a divorce, declared that Harold had orchestrated her detention as retribution for her leaving his household and in order to prevent her from defending herself in the divorce suit. The respondents countered, citing jurisdictional and procedural reasons why the writ of habeas corpus should not lie. After hearing the evidence, Gladys was remanded back into the custody of the superintendent of the King County Juvenile Detention Home.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed for selling liquor without a valid license, Mark J. Wilbur petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that his license was valid, therefore, he was being unlawfully detained by sheriff Ress. Judge Holmes granted the petition. After reviewing evidence, he denied the petition and ordered that Wilbur be remanded back into custody. Wilbur moved the Court for a rehearing, which was overruled. Wilbur then appealed to the NE Supreme Court, who ruled in favor of Wilbur and ordered that he be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: William Ryan enlisted in the U.S. Army. His brother, John Ryan, declared that William was a minor and petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve him, which was granted. John was also a minor, but had been granted power of attorney by the boys' father, also named John Ryan. After hearing the evidence, William was released.

Summary of Proceedings: Arrested and jailed on the charge of "by means of certain bogus checks and worthless checks... to confidence a certain man," Charles Burtt-alias Charles DeFrance-petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus against Chief of Police Hoagland. Judge Cornish granted the petition. In his answer, Hoagland claims that Burtt is "well known to the police officers of the City and other cities of the West, as a professional confidence man." After reviewing the evidence, Judge Cornish allowed the writ and ordered that Burtt be released from custody.

Summary of Proceedings: Grace LaVonne petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her daughter, Virginia LaVonne, from the custody of Sarah Gregory, which was granted. In their response to the writ, Sarah's counsel requested further time to prepare their defense, which was allowed, during which time the judge determined that Grace should have temporary custody of Virginia. At the hearing, Sarah's counsel mounted no defense, and Virginia was remanded to the custody of her mother.

Summary of Proceedings: On July 16, 1886, notary public William J. Houston was tasked with receiving a deposition from Bertha Dogge on a civil case, Hart Bros., et al vs Otto Dogge, Bertha Dogge, and Christian G. Herald. Bertha Dogge refused, and Houston found her in contempt of court and ordered her arrest. On July 22, 1886, Bertha Dogge petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that sheriff Samuel Melick had unlawfully deprived her of her freedom. After examining the evidence, Judge Pound remanded her into the custody of Melick. The next day, Supreme Court Judge Amasa Cobb upheld the decision, but he allowed Bertha to file a writ of error and ruled that Bertha be able to be released on her own recognizance provided that she pay a sum of $250.

Keif petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus. He claimed that Marshall Phillip H. Cooper was illegally detaining him and that his right to due process was violated. Judge Samuel M. Summary of Proceedings: A. B. Burks was being jailed for unspecified reasons. He petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the writ was allowed and Burks released from custody. Since Burks had submitted his petition to the state district court, however, he had been detained on federal charges. The state district court found that the federal court should have "awaited the determination of this action" before commencing its proceedings, confirming that Burks should be released.

Summary of Proceedings: Samuel Jackson, a Chilkat Alaskan Native, was arrested after he "struck one M. A. Reason with his hands and fists" at the Chemawa Indian School. He was charged with assault and battery in the Justice's Court of Salem, Oregon and jailed when he refused to pay the $20 fine. Jackson petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court, which was granted. Jackson argued that the Justice's Court did not have the jurisdiction to try him, since he committed the offense on federal land. After hearing the evidence, Jackson was released. ; A second petition was found in this file. There is no obvious relationship between the two petitions. See hc.case.or.0008.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: John Barton petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his nephew and ward, Horatio Marsden, from Stephen Denny, who was Marsden's brother-in-law. (The documentation vacillates on whether Barton or Marsden was the legal petitioner.) Barton accused Denny of illegally detaining Marsden. Denny countered that he did not detain Marsden, but rather that Marsden chose to live with him; that Barton was abusive; and that, in any case, Marsden had departed from his home. The court granted Barton's petition, but Marsden's fate is unknown.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: William Rotenback was arrested and jailed upon an accusation of forgery after passing a counterfeit bill. Bail was set at $3,000. James Chamberlain petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus on Rotenback's behalf, arguing that the bail was excessive. After hearing the evidence, Rotenback was remanded to the custody of his jailer.

Repository: Missouri State Archives-St. Louis (St. Louis, MO)
Summary of Proceedings: Oliver Filley, the mayor of St. Louis, accused Eliza Edwards of exposing her nine-year-old daughter, Martha, to a house of prostitution she was running, for which offense Martha was arrested and removed from her mother's custody. Eliza petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve her daughter, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, the court ruled that Eliza could regain temporary custody of Martha on the condition that she leave St. Louis "to return with it to it's [sic] father."

Summary of Proceedings: J. J. Blevins petitioned for writs of habeas corpus in the county and circuit courts to retrieve his three young sons, Henry, John, and Thomas, from his father-in-law, Thomas Small, both of which were granted. Smalls claimed that his grandchildren refused to return to their father, saying that they "cried Piteously" at the thought of leaving. Smalls added that Blevins was an unfit parent, and that for the past three years Smalls and his wife, Elizabeth, had been supporting Blevins and the children. After hearing the evidence, the district court judge remanded the three boys to the custody of their father. Blevins and Smalls spent the next two years litigating a property dispute in civil court.

Summary of Proceedings:
Samuel Carr petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus to retrieve his two young sons, Harry and Herbert Carr, from William and Nina Helms, which was granted. A few years earlier, Samuel had placed the boys in the Home for the Friendless in Lincoln, Nebraska, from which institution the Helmses obtained custody of the two. The Helmses did not formally adopt Harry and Herbert, whom they put to work in their traveling minstrel show. After hearing the evidence, Harry and Herbert were released back into the custody of the Home for the Friendless. The judge ordered that Samuel could retrieve his children once he demonstrated that he could properly care for them and after he paid off his debt to the state. 

For background on this case, see the 15 and 16 November 1906 issues of the Hastings Daily Republican. https://www.newspapers.com/clip/97397389/samuel-l-carrs-habeas-corpus-petition/
https://www.newspapers.com/clip/97397717/samuel-l-carrs-habeas-corpus-petition/

Summary of Proceedings: J. H. Rosseter sued C. W. Zaueker for the recovery of a few hundred dollars in the Recorder's Court for the City of Salem, Oregon. The city recorder ordered the arrest of Zaueker and set bail at $240. Zaueker petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus in the Marion County Circuit Court claiming that his detention was illegal, which was granted. After hearing the evidence, Zaueker was released and Rosseter ordered to pay his fees.

After hearing the evidence, Allen was remanded to the custody of his jailer. Charles appealed the decision to the state supreme court, which affirmed the decision of the lower court. Charles then followed up with a related petition to determine the sanity of Allen.

After hearing the evidence, the writ was denied and Wickstrum remanded to the custody of his jailer. He appealed to the state supreme court, which upheld the decision of the lower court.

Site(s) of Significance: Nebraska State Hospital for the Insane (Lincoln, NE)
Summary of Proceedings: Daniel Doodey petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus claiming that he was being unlawfully deprived of his liberty by Sheriff Trompen after he was judged insane by a commission the day previous. Judge Tuttle granted the petition. After hearing evidence, Tuttle allowed the writ and ordered that Doodey be released from custody. The next day, Doodey filed for divorce from his wife, Mary Ann Doodey, claiming that she gave false testimony that resulted in him being institutionalized in an insane asylum. The Judge granted the divorce, but sided with Mary Ann and granted her custody of their children.
